content:
The workload of an instructional designer (ID) at a college in the U.S. can be difficult to quantify in terms of specific projects or committees, as it can vary widely depending on the needs of the institution and the specific responsibilities of the ID. However, to give you a sense of what might constitute a full-time (40-hour a week) instructional designer workload, here are some additional factors that can contribute to an ID's workload:

1. Number of courses supported: IDs may be responsible for supporting a certain number of courses per semester or academic year, depending on the size of the institution and the availability of other IDs or support staff. For example, an ID might be responsible for supporting 10-12 courses per semester.
2. Type of courses supported: IDs may support courses in a particular department or program, or they may work with a variety of courses across the institution. Depending on the type of courses they support, IDs may need to have expertise in specific subject areas or pedagogical approaches.
3. Technology tools and systems: IDs may need to be proficient in a variety of technology tools and systems, such as learning management systems, content authoring tools, and video conferencing software. They may also need to stay up-to-date on emerging technologies and trends in educational technology.
4. Collaborations and partnerships: IDs may work closely with faculty members, administrators, and other staff across the institution to design and develop courses and instructional materials. They may also collaborate with external partners, such as vendors or educational organizations.
5. Professional development and research: IDs may need to engage in ongoing professional development and research to stay current with trends and best practices in instructional design and educational technology.

Overall, a full-time instructional designer workload can be quite diverse, and can involve a variety of projects, collaborations, and responsibilities. The specific workload of an ID will depend on the needs of their institution and the priorities of their department or program.
